titleStmt.title: Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Pennsylvania University Museum, E 16265

respStmt.resp: Edited by Michael Marx in collaboration with Tobias J. Jocham et. al. TEI version created by Yasmin Faghihi and Huw Jones

availability.p: Image credits: Courtesy of Pennsylvania University Museum Philadelphia.

summary.p: 1 fol. on parchment; Shelfmark: E 16265; Qurʾānic Text: Q 27:44-27:45, Q 27:48-27:50; 7-8 lines per page; Dimensions: 119 x 97mm; Script style: new style; Estimated date of production: 850-1000 (?).
The catalogue of Arabic manuscripts kept by the University Museum in Philaldelphia, written by Giorgio Levi Della Vida gives the following information (Levi Della Vida 1981, p. 164f.):

"138. (Plate XX) Inv. E. 16265. 5th century A. H./11th century A. D. Cream colored, thin parchment 9.7 x 11.9 cm. Written on both faces in black ink. Seven lines, and traces of an eighth line are extant. Upper half from a sheet, the original height of which was ca. 19 cm. The full width has been preserved, and the upper, outer and inner margins, measuring 4.3,2 and 3 cm, are intact. From the Ellen W. Harrison Collection. Recto: Kor. 27,44 يختصمون - انه. Verso: 27,48 (49) مكرا (51) 50 - المدينة (second). Late "Kūfic", closely similar to no. 45 of Moritz's Arabic Paleography. Diacritical dots are black, vowel marks are expressed by red dots, shadda is blue and hamza yellow. Verses are divided by gold seven-petaled rosettes; a verse divider is found after verse 44, where only the Cairo edition has a continuous verse, as against all other numerations (see A. Spitaler, Die Verszählung des Koran, p. 49). A larger, nine-petaled rosette is found after verse 45, and a pear-shaped divider after verse 44, which is 45 according to the Baṣra and Damascus numbering. On the verso, the end of verse 49, which is 50 according to the Baṣra and Damascus numbering, is followed by a large violet circle surrounded by golden palmettes and bearing in its middle the letter nūn (last letter of خمسون "fifty") in gold: the same device is repeated in larger size on the outer margin (the colors have faded off), where the word خمسون is written in extenso. Another fragmentary sheet from the same copy is extant in the following number [= Inv. E 16264 M]."
